I would say that most parents of high schoolers right now -- and I am one -- are primarily worried about our children being able to get jobs and make a DECENT living.

As we now live in a winner take all society where an average wage earning job doesn't offer -- at least where I live -- anything close to a decent working class life, parents see a 'name college' as one of the few empirically demonstrable ways that might help their children make a living.

It is a pity that our society is like this, but it is, so parents' panic is understandable, no?

The stress does not come at all from mother's who need their kids to accomplish what they did not do themselves. The opposite. Many want their kids to have the options open to them that they have learned from experience comes from doing well in high school and college.  We know it is a hard world out there and certain things that have helped us, can help our kids .  You can agree or disagree with how far to go to push kids in high school or how important you think a degree from a top school is, but don't judge parents' motivations as selfish.

The author seems to have a need to feed her own ego through her daughter's success rather than having a sincere concern about her daughter's future happiness.  Sadly there are  many parents who fit this profile.  What is most troubling is that the author seems to understand intellectually that "success" cannot be defined narrowly to include only one "track", yet she  appears unable to accept this emotionally.  She is unable to let go of her dream of an "elite" education for her daughter though she admits this might not be the recipe for success she seeks.  I do not mean to sound unkind, but i think the author and others who think like her need to put more focus on what they themselves are doing to improve The Human Condition instead of living their lives in the reflected glow of their children. If her daughter is indeed as bright as the author thinks she is, she'll make her own way without her mother having sleepless nights about her future.  It is frankly sad to see anyone this stressed out by the need to define themselves through their child's accomplishments.  Unfortunately, such behavior is rampant in today's society.

My hastily chosen 'room mate' grabbed the vanity dresser top at each hotel.  Another felt entitled to the third bathroom towel.  But when I was alone in Calcutta one night on a tour for which I had paid the supplement, the bed began shaking in the middle of the night.  Before I was conscious enough to figure out what was going on I thought, "this is the limit."  Turned out to be an earthquake in the north.

I once was on a solo trip to Italy. Part of the time I joined a tour where I was forced to share a room with someone assigned to me. I went out one night on my own and when I came back, I found my roommate screaming for help. She was stuck in the bathtub. Too big all around and arms too weak to push herself up and out. She was angry that I had gone out and left her there but I felt I had no obligation to spend all my time with her just because I had to sleep in the same room at night. She was also obsessed with the drains, claiming that every room we stayed in had some kind of poison gas coming out of the drain.

It was a memorable trip. The best part was on my own. The part with that crazy person was the worst. I can laugh about it now but at the time I could barely wait till the the few days of the tour were over. Luckily I was able to leave the tour early and get back to being on my own.

I wish singles were accommodated as singles and not forced into these situations.

When calorie counts are off it is not necessarily a long term issue only. If the calorie count is off because the carbohydrate count is off, it can be a much more immediate problem for someone with diabetes who may be relying on that information to control blood sugar. And with more and more of us suffering from diabetes, this is not a vague hypothetical potentially affecting a tiny share of the population.

Surely it should, at a minimum have been extended for a year or phased in over a three-four year period. Clearly if either party had loudly proposed that, the other could not have conceivably opposed. In that sense both were equally responsible. .

But Krugman does not have to say this or believe it. Surely he can say that no President does anything on a fake debt ceiling, but tells the opposition to go ahead on default on debt if it wants.

I grew up in Connecticut and went to a private all-female high school and college on scholarship.Without Affirmative Action I may have missed out on these opportunities. When I graduated from college in Boston I couldn't wait to leave. While there I witnessed white men throwing eggs on black girls, white men with bats leaving a Red Sox game looking to beat any black person they saw. I witnessed so many incidents of racism that I refused to take a job there after graduation.

When I returned to CT I was stopped repeatedly for driving a BMW. My husband worked for a delivery co. at the time and he wore a uniform. People would lock their doors when he approached and close the elevator in his face!

How many of you have been stopped by the police driving home from school or work and pulled out of the car for a search of the vehicle over and over, be handcuffed by the police while they searched but never found drugs or guns? My son has. He was stopped for walking in our neighborhood with a gun put to his head by a police officer, questioned about what he was doing there. He was walking from his friend's house who lives in our neighborhood. My son was 17 and in high school when these incidents began. These incidents are not unique as I had to tell my son, a clean-cut looking young man. Racism still exists in a big way. If you think the racists are not in positions of power, you are wrong. Unfortunately Affirmative Action is still needed as long as racial profiling exists..

Henry George wanted to tax capital gains on *land*. He did not want to tax work, either directly through wages or indirectly through capital gains, on the work product of labor or management. His idea was a good one, and should be implemented in Manhattan as soon as possible.

A few dozen wealthy families pay low, low property taxes in Manhattan while having hundreds of millions or billions of dollars each, while moderately well-to-do people are chased out of Manhattan by the city income tax. It makes no sense. The land can't leave -- it's the one thing a municipality should tax. It should tax the value of the raw land, at 5% per annum.

Capital gains and carried interest income is also not subject to the 15.3% payroll tax the rest of us pay.

The rich are very happy about this loophole.

I don't know where you get your data from Mike Hihn, but it clearly does not measure up. According to Money magazine, 47% of all capital gains went to the top 1%. And those "pension gains" that you speak of are by law deferred until the retiree begins drawing retirement income, with the tax rate depending on the retirees income level. Therefore if the retiree earns the same in retirement income as when working, his gains will be taxed at the same level as earned income.

By comparison, the upper income investor deposits those gains at a lower tax rate than earned income. If the majority of his income is from capital gains, it is a major tax savings. And since they get this break every year, indexing doesn't apply.

Please explain just how this is a better deal for the middle class.

One of the big culprits is the low tax rates for 'capital gains.' Capital gains are unearned income, mostly profits from gambling on Wall St or long term increases in value due to, for example, growth of urban areas which increases the value of nearby farms.

These increases in value are not related to job creation, and there is no legitimate reason to tax them at half the rate for equivalent wage income or salary income. Almost all of the capital gains income goes to the 1%. One theorist, Henry George, thought that ONLY capital gains should be taxed.

Capital gains should be taxed equally to ordinary earned income. President Lincoln thought so, or that it should be taxed higher than earned income. This would be another step towards fair treatment for the bottom, the top and the middle.

The current low tax rate for 'capital gains' is immoral and harmful to everyone except the 99%.

who are you to say what is best for another person or another animal? you don't know- you only know what has been best for you.
as PEOPLE we don't "put down" our loved ones to keep them from suffering death. in this case, the young man provided palliative care much the same as we do for our family members. because the cat convulsed does NOT mean he was hurting- during seizures/convulsions most are unconscious.
